revision.text:
{{Automatic taxobox |image = file:Casaleia eocenica SMFMEI5565.jpg |image_caption = ''C. eocenica'' [[holotype]] |fossil_range = {{fossil_range|Lutetian|Middle Miocene|[[Lutetian]] - [[Middle Miocene]]}} |taxon = Casaleia |authority = Pagliano & Scaramozzino, 1990 |type_species = ''Protamblyopone inversa'' |type_species_authority = Dlussky, 1981 |synonyms = *''Protamblyopone'' <small>Dlussky, 1981</small> }} '''''Casaleia''''' is an [[extinct]] genus of [[ants]] in the [[Formicidae|formicid]] subfamily [[Amblyoponinae]] described by Pagliano & Scaramozzino in 1990 from fossils found in [[Europe]].<ref name=Bolton1994>{{cite book |last1=Bolton |first1=B. |title=Identification Guide to the Ant Genera of the World |date=June 1994 |publisher=Harvard University Press |location=Cambridge, Massachusetts |isbn=0674442806 |page=164 |edition=1st}}</ref> The genus contains four species dating from the [[Eocene]] to [[Miocene]], '''''Casaleia eocenica''''', '''''Casaleia inversa''''', '''''Casaleia longiventris''''', '''''Casaleia orientalis'''''.<ref name=Dlussky2012>{{Cite journal |last1= Dlussky |first1= G.M. |last2= Wedmann |first2= S. | title = The poneromorph ants (Hymenoptera, Formicidae: Amblyoponinae, Ectatomminae, Ponerinae) of Grube Messel, Germany: High biodiversity in the Eocene |journal= [[Journal of Systematic Palaeontology]] |volume= 10 |issue= 4 |pages= 725–753 |year= 2012 | doi = 10.1080/14772019.2011.628341}}{{subscription needed|via=[[Taylor & Francis]]}}</ref><ref name="Dlussky2014">{{cite journal|last1=Dlussky |first1=G.M. |last2=Putyatina |first2=T.S. |year=2014 |title=Early Miocene ants (Hymenoptera, Formicidae) from Radoboj, Croatia |journal=Neues Jahrbuch für Geologie und Paläontologie - Abhandlungen |volume=272 |issue=3 |pages=237–285 |doi=10.1127/0077-7749/2014/0409}}</ref><ref name="Dlussky2015">{{Cite journal |last1=Dlussky |first1=G. M. |last2=Rasnitsyn |first2=A. P. |last3=Perfilieva |first3=K. S. |year=2015 |title=The ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) of Bol'shaya Svetlovodnaya (late Eocene of Sikhote-Alin, Russian far east) |journal=Caucasian Entomological Bulletin |volume=11 |issue=1 |pages=131–152 |doi= }}</ref>
== History and classification == The species placed in ''Casaleia'' have a varied history, with the [[type species]] ''Casaleia inversa'' originally described by Gennady Dlussky in 1981 as ''"Protamblyopone" inversa''. The fossil was recovered from [[Middle Miocene]] age sediments exposed in the Chon-Tyz mine, [[Naryn Region]], Kyrgyzstan.<ref name="Antweb">{{cite web |url=https://www.antweb.org/description.do?genus=casaleia&species=inversa&rank=species&project=allantwebants |title=Species: ''Casaleia inversa'' |date= |website=antweb.org |publisher=[[AntWeb]] |accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref> However "Protamblyopone" was already used by [[William Morton Wheeler]] as a subgenus of ''[[Amblyopone]]''. To correct the [[homonym]] status, the species was moved to the new genus ''Casaleia'' by Pagliano and Scaramozzino in a 1990 paper.<ref name="Dlussky2014"/>
The second species in the genus, ''C. eocenica'', is of [[Lutetian]] age, and was recovered as a solitary [[compression fossil|compression-impression fossil]] preserved in a layer of soft [[sedimentary rock]]. Along with other well preserved insect fossils, the ''C. eocenica'' specimen was collected from layers of the Lutetian [[Messel pit]] [[World Heritage Site]]. The formation is composed of brown coals, oil shales, and [[bituminous shale]], which preserved numerous insects, fish, birds, reptiles, and terrestrial mammals as a notable [[lagerstätten]]. The area is a preserved [[maar|maar lake]] which initially formed approximately 47 million years ago as the result of volcanic explosions.<ref name="Dlussky2009">{{cite journal |last1=Dlussky |first1=GM |last2=Wappler |first2=T |last3=Wedmann |first3=S |year=2009 |title=Fossil ants of the genus ''Gesomyrmex'' Mayr (Hymenoptera, Formicidae) from the Eocene of Europe and remarks on the evolution of arboreal ant communities |journal=Zootaxa |volume=2031 |pages=1–20 |url=http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2009/f/z02031p020f.pdf}}</ref> The fossil was described by Dlussky and Sonja Wedmann in a 2012 paper on the [[Poneromorph subfamilies|poneromorph]] ants of Messel. The [[specific name (zoology)|specific epithet]] "eocenica" is derived from the Eocene age of the fossil. At the time of description, the fossil was preserved in the collections of the Forschungsstation Grube Messel as number FIS MeI 5565.<ref name=Dlussky2012/>
''C. longiventris'' was originally described 132 years before ''C. inversa'' and the erection of a new genus for the species.<ref name="Dlussky2014"/> The species was based on a group of seven separate fossil ants, which were preserved as [[compression fossil]]s in sedimentary rock from the [[Radoboj]] area of what is now Croatia. The deposits are the result of sedimentation in an inland sea basin, possibly a shallow lagoon environment, during the [[Burdigalian]] of the [[Early Miocene]]. The fossil impressions are preserved in [[micrite]] limestones, resulting in low quality preservation of fine details. The fossils were first studied by [[Oswald Heer]], then a professor with the [[University of Zürich]], who placed the fossils into the genus ''[[Formica]]'' as ''F. longiventris'' in 1849.<ref name="Dlussky2014"/> This placement was not changed until a re-examination of two of Heers type specimens was published in 2014. Examination by Dlussky and Putyatina of two of Heers "[[syntype]]s" resulted in the removal of the species from ''Formica'' and placement into ''Casaleia''. Of the two specimens, one was designated [[lectotype]] for the species, while the second was determined not to belong to the genus.<ref name="Dlussky2014"/>
''C. orientalis'' was described in 2015 from a single holotype gyne missing its head. The fossil was recovered from the [[late Eocene]] Bol’shaya Svetlovodnaya fossil site, in the Sikhote-Alin area of far-eastern Russia. The [[type specimen]] numbered PIN 3429/1174 is currently preserved in the A.A. Borissiak Paleontological Institute fossil collections of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]]. The Bol’shaya Svetlovodnaya site preserves diatomaceous sediments from a small lake which existed near an active volcanic center. The diatomites have been grouped as either the Maksimovka formation or Salibez Formation, and the age range for the fossils is varied, ranging from upper Eocene to Upper Oligocene. Dlussky, Rasnitsyn, and Perfilieva opted to treat the fossil age as that of probably Priabonian. They coined the [[species|specific epithet]] from the [[Latin]] "''orientalis''", meaning "eastern", in reference to the type locality.<ref name="Dlussky2015"/>
==Description== In all three species the broad abdomen rests against the [[Thorax (insect anatomy)|thorax]] with a single node petiole connecting. The eyes are sometimes not present on worker caste individuals, but in all castes where they are present they are placed just behind the mid length of the head capsule. In the known gynes the antennae are twelve segments and [[geniculate]] in structure, while the mandibles are triangular.
===''C. eocenica''=== The type fossil for ''C. eocenica'' is a winged female gyne that was preserved as a dorsal imprint in the matrix. Overall the body length as preserved is {{convert|4.9|mm|in|abbr=on}} with fore-wings that are {{convert|3.2|mm|in|abbr=on}} long. The eyes are placed nearly at the midpoint of the head which is a little longer than its width. The antennae differ from ''C. inversa'' by having a [[antenna (biology)|scape]] which extends beyond the back corner of the head. The fore-wings have a vein structure that has resulted in closed cells 1 + 2r, 3r, rm and mcu.<ref name=Dlussky2012/>
===''C. inversa''=== ''C. inversa'' is medium length for the genus, being {{convert|6.5|mm|in|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Dlussky2014"/>
===''C. longiventris''=== The largest of the species, ''C. longiventris'' has a body length of {{convert|10|mm|in|abbr=on}}, and a hind-wing length of {{convert|6.4|mm|in|abbr=on}}. The [[mesosoma]] is elongated compared to the other two species and additionally separating the three. Neither the antennae or the fore-wings are preserved on the single examined lectotype.<ref name="Dlussky2014"/>
===''C. orientalis''=== The single fossil is incomplete, but estimates give the length of {{convert|5.0|mm|in}}. The front are of the mesosoma has a convex outline in profile. Due to the preservation positioning of the gyne, comparison to the other species was not possible.<ref name="Dlussky2015"/>
